At 22:34 10/11/2005, you wrote:
>Colin Green wrote:
>
> >
> >2) Changing the fitness function. We choose a function based on the
> >problem at hand, so it doesn't seem sensible to switch to a different
> >function. But often we come up with different ways of evaluating netwoks
> >for a given problem and we often have discussions about what is the best
> >function. What if we were to code up a few of theses different functions
> >and allow NEAT to periodically switch between them. This then could be
> >something akin to an extinction event occuring in nature and changing
> >the fitness landscape.
> >
> >
> >
>.... or if your function has a bunch of measures that are weighted to
>give a final fitness score you could just change the weighting
>occasionally.

I have been toying with this.  e.g. because TTT-PPS involves testing 
each individual over 620-odd boards, you could regard the fitness of 
each individual as a vector or values (one value for each 
board).  This still reduces to a single overall fitness if you sum 
over the vector, but by keeping the values separate for some 
purposes, you might be keeping information that would otherwise be discarded.

((This is not specific to TTT, it would apply just as well to any 
case where the score is built as a sum over a set of test 
cases.  Even co-evolution might be expressible this way, e.g. if each 
individual plays against every other member of the population, then 
that set of results is a fitness vector as well.))

You can use this to identify individuals with important new features, 
even if their overall score is low.  e.g. given two individuals, we 
have the simple comparison of scores:

DScore(1, 2) = Score_1 - Score_2.

But we also can divide up the test-cases according to who passed them:

CommonScore(1, 2) = Sum(Cases_Both_Pass);
CommonFail(1, 2) = Sum(Cases_Both_Fail);
Advantage(1, 2) = Sum(Cases_1_Passes_But_2_Fails);
Advantage(2, 1) = Sum(Cases_2_Passes_But_1_Fails);

Thus, when 2 has a lower overall score than 1, but a non-zero 
Advantage(2, 1).  That tells us that although 2 is a step back in 
absolute fitness, it has discovered something that 1 cannot do 
(especially if 1 is the population leader, because the leader is 
least likely to be missing anything obvious and least-likely to be 
able to acquire a new feature without losing some existing score).

Which might be a strong case for either:
a) 2 being regarded as fitter than naive fitness woudl suppose, or,
b) splitting 2 off into a new species to see if it can improve on its 
new feature (with the scope to merge it back later)
c) trying hard to merge 1 and 2 right now

         Ian

p.s. I don't really know anything about it, but doesn't one of the 
classifier approaches work a little like this?  Maybe pareto?

In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
